children.text: The “why” of this project spans subfields in rhetorical, cultural, and media studies. Flint’s direct voice channeling was rigorously tested throughout his 40+ years as an active medium; researchers and skeptics would attend his seances to tape over his mouth, affix sensors and microphones to his throat to detect vibrations, or to measure the volume of water Flint could hold in his mouth before, during, and after a seance. Flint was regularly recorded and tested by the London-based Society for Psychical Research (SPR), which boasted cutting-edge parapsychological testing technologies, including infrared telescopes and cameras and tamper-proof cabinets for mediums to perform inside of.

Though he was repeatedly accused of fraud, the results of these tests largely concluded that Flint was not in fact speaking during his seances–no vibrations were registered, and no water was spilled. However, I’m far less interested in whether you, or I, or the people who attended Flint’s sittings actually “believe” in his ability, or in the presence of an ectoplasmic voice box in the room (though I seriously hope there was).

Instead, I think Flint’s contact with ideals of truth and metrics of science are interesting from a rhetorical standpoint; what can we learn about twentieth century scientific discourses from listening to Flint’s presentation of truth, honesty, and credibility to audiences invested in “proving” Flint’s claims about reality? Though the audio featured in this project was not recorded by the SPR or other scientific organizations, the recordings do reveal plenty about how Flint, his interlocutors, and the projected voices of spirit people imagine truth.

Listening to Flint's unique method of independent direct voice mediumship also offers glimpses into conceptions of the body and experiences of embodiment after death. As the voices of the deceased (which Flint calls "spirit people") make their ways into the recording, they are physically disembodied, but sound just as clear as those who are physically in the room (including Flint and those who recorded him and sat for his seances).

The voices projected through the ectoplasmic voice box offer insight into the body after death, and explicitly link material reality of death to the validity of Flint's seances. For example, in his channeling of Arthur Conan Doyle, the voice box (presumably Doyle himself), says:

But I do say this: any man or woman who sincerely seeks truth will find it. I know there will be some who will criticise when they listen to this. There will be some who will make excuses. There will be some that will say, "Oh well, how do we know it is him?" There will be some who will say, "Oh, of course, you know he had a cleft mouth, and that does not sound like his voice." But if they are intelligent they will know damn well I don’t have a cleft mouth over here.

In this clip, Doyle tells Flint and his recorders (Betty Greene and George Woods) that anyone who doubts the voice they're hearing hasn't fully considered the reality of the spirit body, which apparently corrects certain conditions the spirit person may have experienced before their death. The quality of the voices of the deceased during Flint's seances were a critique frequently lobbed by skeptics, but in this instance, Doyle names the apparent change in his speaking voice as a condition of his credibility; of course speak impediments don't exist in the perfection of the afterlife. Again, I'm not particularly concerned with whether or how our personal beliefs align with these claims, but hope to engage what they offer our understandings of the rhetoricity of embodiment.

title: Rhetorics of Science and the Body (or, the "why?")
